For years, the Oakland Tribune newspaper published an annual homicide map.
But a few years ago, it decided to try something new.
The idea was to go beyond merely posting crime stats on a city grid.
So the Tribune created an interactive community project on its Web site called Not Just a Number.
The online homicide map includes photographs of the victims, and it allowed friends, family, neighbors or even strangers to exchange stories, music or anything else in a file attached to the photo.
But last year, families of some of the victims complained about the photos.
Many of the victims' pictures on the homicide map were mugshots, and families said those shots criminalized their loved ones.
In response, the mugshots were removed for a time.
But this year, the paper decided to continue using the mugshots.
Martin Reynolds is the editor of the Oakland Tribune, and he joins me now to talk about that decision.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
Why did you decide to go back to using the mugshots?

Well, as we started gathering all the photographs for this year's map, we, of course, decided to - as we had in the past - put out a call, requesting family members to provide photographs that they may want for the map.
We also used another source, which was the California Department of Motor Vehicles.
But once we got all these pieces together, about a third of the map was without images.
So we had a debate amongst ourselves about, well, what's more important?
Do you show the faces?
Do you just list the person's name and where they were killed and the date?
And I ultimately decided that it was more important to show the face, rather just the number.
You know, the whole spirit of Not Just a Number was that very point, that these people are not just numbers.
And although they're listed numerically on the map, they're not just numbers and we need to see their faces, even if those mugshots come from the police department.
And just to be clear, you use the mugshots only if the families don't provide a personal photo.
Correct.
And if you had the option, you would instead use a photo provided by the DMV, the Department of Motor Vehicles.
Yeah.
Which is a more - obviously, a more benign source.
Have there been any families that have stepped forward and said we don't want our kids' - our loved ones' picture in the paper?
Yeah, there have been.
There definitely have been.
And...
And have you honored that request?
Most definitely.
Was there a debate within the newsroom about journalistic integrity?
Because if you had the option of using mugshots, in some of these cases, it might suggest that the victim was caught up in a lifestyle that may have contributed to their death.
Right.
Well, there was debate.

And there certainly was debate last year, when we initially, the first time Not Just a Number kicked off, and the folks who were really leading the charge were going around talking to families and hearing, you know, finally getting the feedback that people didn't like these mugshots.
You know, there was debate that time about, you know, the old school journalists were like, well, you use what you got.
And these other folks were like, well, no. We're going to betray the people who let us into their homes and told us their stories if we use these mugshots.
So that debate, of course, continued this year, because Not Just a Number, we're continuing to add to it, continuing to build on that legacy.
This Not Just a Number project was created by Katy Newton and Sean Connelly.
Yeah.
What was the purpose of this?
What were you hoping to accomplish?

Well, the coverage of crime for so long has been not really solution-oriented and not taking an approach where, as a news organization, we say, well, you know, we need to help to try and present solutions.

And also sort of capturing in a different way the data so that you could see the correlations between, you know, where people killed, what they were killed by, you know, who they were, what their demographics were so that we can begin to sort really shape a picture of what the crime issue is, and then maybe better report on it and better illuminate the problem.
The homicide rate has continued to increase since this map was introduced a few years ago.
Was there a hope that something like this might help reduce those numbers, reverse those numbers in the city?
I think we would be very naive to think that our map would somehow serve as a means or a wake up call to those people most involved in this lifestyle and living this way.
I don't think we had a hope that it would reduce it.
I think we just hoped that we could better cover the issue, and in doing so, add something to the conversation.
Martin Reynolds is the editor of the Oakland Tribune.
Thanks so much for speaking with us.
Thank you for having me.
I appreciate it.

The notion that garlic is good for your heart took a hit today.
A study in the ""Archives of Internal Medicine"" finds that neither cloves of garlic nor garlic supplements can lower bad cholesterol.
NPR's Allison Aubrey reports.
Chef Nino Bruzzo is 68 years old, but he says memories of his boyhood can come back instantly with one smell.
I grow up in Italy.
My mother, she usually cook, and I grow up with the smell, the garlic.
Which is now the smell that fills the kitchen of Luigi's, the Washington restaurant he runs with his brother.
As he stirs a fresh garlic into some olive oil, he says this is the foundation of lots of dishes, from the calamari to the sautÃÂ©ed mushrooms.
I give it special taste, you know, a flavor.
Very good.
I love it.
Growing up, he says his mom filled his plate with these garlicky dishes, but she also filled his head with the idea that garlic keeps you healthy.
That's Stanford nutrition researcher Christopher Gardner.
He and a team decided to take a harder look at garlic's health benefits.

With grant money from the National Institutes of Health, they enrolled about 200 middle-aged volunteers, all of whom had moderately high levels of cholesterol but were not taking medicines to treat it.
Gardner says his first hurdle was getting the volunteers to eat the stuff.
How do you give people in a research study raw garlic six days a week for six months?
That was the question that we faced in the beginning, and we really didn't want to do it unless we could use raw garlic, because we thought that should be the gold standard.
They decided to mash up the garlic into a condiment spread and then put exactly one clove's worth of garlic spread onto each of nearly 30,000 gourmet sandwiches.

So this is a portabella, and this is an eggplant, and it's a salmon patty, and it's a veggie burger on a whole-grain bun, and we even went to the length of having the biochemists look at the active ingredients of the raw garlic in the condiment after being in a refrigerator for one, two and three days.
Just to be certain that the active ingredients hadn't lost their punch.
Gardner says some of the volunteers who were not eating the sandwiches were instead asked to take a garlic supplement every day, while others were asked to swallow a placebo pill.
At the end of the study, it turns out that nobody had lower cholesterol, not the gourmet sandwich eaters or the supplement takers.
We were so disappointed because nothing happened.
The real garlic didn't work and neither of the pills worked, and this isn't that they worked a little, and it wasn't statistically significant.
There was no movement across the entire six months.
Gardner says personally, he was crushed.

He really thought fresh garlic would lower bad cholesterol, but since it doesn't, he says he'll move on and maybe check to see if there are some antibacterial benefits or perhaps an anti-inflammatory effect that helps the body.
As for chef Nino Bruzzo, he still thinks his mother and grandmother were right - garlic brings out the very best in food.
